I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will prepare a project to improve roads in the Lao People’s 
Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  and  Viet  Nam  comprising  part  of  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion (GMS)1 Northeastern Corridor. In January and February 2008, Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) missions met with the Ministry of Public Works and Transport (MPWT) in the Lao 
PDR and the Viet Nam Road Administration (VRA) of the Ministry of Transport in Viet Nam, the 
proposed  executing  agencies,  to  discuss  the  TA  and  reach  an  agreement  on  its  impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference.2 The missions also conducted site visits to the project area. The TA and ensuing 
grant for the Lao PDR and loan for Viet Nam are included in the Greater Mekong Subregion 
indicative rolling regional cooperation operations business plan (2008–2010).3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  One of the major impediments to building subregional economic cooperation is the poor 
state of the basic infrastructure. Under the GMS Program, ADB is supporting the completion 
and  expansion  of  strategic  economic  corridors,  typically  centered  on  transport  corridors. 
Direction for a new transport sector strategy and program was provided by the GMS leaders at 
the GMS summit in Kunming in July 2005. They highlighted the key economic development role 
of an efficient and comprehensive cross-border transport system in the GMS. In support of this, 
ADB financed the preparation of a GMS transport sector strategy study.4 This stresses the 
critical importance of completing transport corridors to link the subregion and promote trade and 
investment. It recommends that the overall objective should be the establishment of a well built, 
seamless, multi-modal subregional transport network to fully connect the GMS. The strategic 
objectives include completing transport corridors to link the subregion and promote trade and 
investment; coordinating strategies to ensure that transport corridors evolve into economic 
corridors, enabling agricultural diversification, industrialization, and the creation of employment 
opportunities; reducing nonphysical barriers to the movement of people, goods, and services; 
and accelerating the implementation of such arrangements as the GMS Cross-Border Transit 
Agreement.  
 
3.  The GMS Northeastern Corridor (encompassing Nanning in Guangxi province, People’s 
Republic  of  China;  Hanoi  and  Thanh  Hoa  in  Viet  Nam;  Louangphrabang,  Lao  PDR;  and 
Bangkok, Thailand) is one of the corridors identified in the transport sector strategy study and 
links northeastern Lao PDR and northern Viet Nam. Many of the roads in the transport corridor 
are  in  good  condition  or  are  being  improved.  For  example,  the  Northern  GMS  Transport 
Network Improvement Project,5 approved in 2007, is improving a 370 kilometer (km) section of 
the Northeastern Corridor in the Lao PDR, specifically the section of Route 4 running southwest 
from the Louangphrabang area to the Lao PDR–Thailand border. However, the sections of the 
corridor in northeastern Lao PDR and northern Viet Nam need substantial improvement if they 
are to become part of a fully functioning transport corridor.6 The governments of the Lao PDR

4.  The  midterm  review  of  the  GMS  strategic  framework  (2002–2012) 7   found  that 
investments  in  physical  infrastructure  to  enable  connectivity  should  be  complemented  by 
investments that enhance competitiveness. This finding is relevant to the GMS Northeastern 
Corridor. The Lao PDR and Viet Nam have recently constructed new border posts at the Na 
Meo border crossing, which is at the junction of the Lao PDR Route 6 and Viet Nam Route 217, 
as well as at other border crossings in the project area. However, improvements in border-
crossing procedures and border controls are needed. ADB TA is helping to develop the GMS 
governments’ capacity to manage cross-border transport and trade. The recently approved 
regional TA for Enhancing Transport and Trade Facilitation in the GMS8 will provide support for 
institutional capacity building to strengthen transport and trade facilitation, in order to maximize 
the efficient movement of people and goods along the improved transport infrastructure in the 
GMS corridors. The TA consultants will work closely with regulatory agencies including customs 
and sanitary and phytosanitary agencies in the areas of transport facilitation; border inspection 
measures, including sanitary and phytosanitary measures; business and logistics support; and 
regional information sharing.  
 
5.  Economic development and poverty reduction are key issues in the project area. The 
project area is located in the provinces of Houaphanh in the Lao PDR and Thanh Hoa in Viet 
Nam, both of which have high rates of poverty. Houaphanh in northeastern Lao PDR is one of 
the poorest provinces in the country. Five of its eight districts are included among the 47 poorest 
districts of the Lao PDR, and 78% of Houaphanh’s 758 villages are classified as poor, with the 
majority of the population relying on upland agriculture. Thanh Hoa province is the northernmost 
province of Viet Nam’s central coastal provinces. Three of the five districts of the province 
through  which  the  project  road  passes  are  designated  as  poor.  The  percentage  of  the 
population living below the poverty line in these three districts ranges from 24% to 59%. 
 
6.  ADB is implementing projects to facilitate economic growth and poverty reduction in 
specific locations in the project area. In the Lao PDR project area, a Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction (JFPR) grant for Alternative Livelihood for Upland Ethnic Groups in Houaphanh 
Province9 aims to improve alternative sources of livelihood for ethnic groups in two districts. In 
the Viet Nam project area, ADB-financed TA10 is currently preparing the proposed Thanh Hoa 
City Comprehensive Socioeconomic Development Project. The TA will identify key strategic 
areas for the province and city’s economic development by assisting in (i) finalizing the master 
plan for provincial and regional economic development; (ii) prioritizing investment proposals for 
the city and the province on the basis of their impact on economic growth; and (iii) preparing 
investment  proposals  for  official  development  assistance,  private  sector  participation,  and 
strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises. In addition, a JFPR grant for the Thanh 
Hoa Province Small Scale Infrastructure Investments and Services in Urban and Peri-Urban

Areas  is  also  being  implemented  in  Thanh  Hoa  province.11  The  grant  is  assisting  in  the 
implementation of decentralized planning policies to bridge the gaps between centrally driven 
urban  service  networks  and  the  marginalized  urban  poor  through  a  community-driven 
development approach. The grant will provide local governments and community groups with 
the capacity and skills necessary to implement decentralized and participatory infrastructure 
planning activities. While these projects will improve economic conditions and reduce poverty in 
their specific project areas, broader economic growth in the project area will require better 
infrastructure to improve links to ports and to other GMS areas that are growing more rapidly.  
 
7.  The road sectors in the Lao PDR and Viet Nam are unable to fulfill their potential to 
facilitate economic growth in their respective countries because of insufficient financing for road 
maintenance,  inadequate  development  of  the  physical  transport  network,  and  insufficient 
capacity  of  transport  sector  institutions.  In  the  Lao  PDR,  the  World  Bank  and  ADB  are 
addressing the insufficient financing for road maintenance through projects providing financing 
to the Road Maintenance Fund and technical assistance to improve its operations. The World 
Bank, bilateral agencies (including Sweden, Republic of Korea, Thailand), ADB, and others 
have  provided  financing  for  upgrading  the  national  road  network,  including  ADB-financed 
projects to improve the GMS corridors. The World Bank, Sweden, ADB, and  others have 
provided  financing  for  strengthening  the  capacity  of  transport  sector  institutions.  ADB  will 
continue this support through the proposed TA on Building Sector Program Readiness in the 
Transport Sector now being processed for approval in 2008. Consulting services to improve 
road safety12 are also being provided under ADB road improvement projects. In Viet Nam, the 
Japan Bank for International Cooperation, the World Bank, and ADB have provided financing for 
improving the national road network, including ADB-financed projects to improve the GMS 
corridors. Maintenance of national roads is being supported by the World-Bank-funded Road 
Network Improvement Project,13 which has developed a standardized road maintenance system 
for application to both national and provincial roads throughout Viet Nam. The Road Network 
Improvement Project includes a component for strengthening road maintenance financing and 
management  that  will  prepare  and  implement  a  framework  to  improve  cost  recovery  and 
planning, budgeting, and monitoring of maintenance of road assets. ADB’s program for the 
transport sector also includes a proposed TA for Capacity Development in the Transport Sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the Project will be more efficient transport infrastructure in the GMS 
Northeastern Corridor and the Lao PDR and Viet Nam national road networks. The TA outcome 
will be the preparation of a project design and feasibility study for the Second Northern GMS 
Transport Network Improvement Project to a level suitable for ADB financing. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
9.  By  improving  the  efficiency  of  transport  in  the  GMS  Northeastern  Corridor  and  on 
associated rural access roads, the ensuing project will increase economic growth and reduce 
poverty in two of the poorer provinces of the Lao PDR and Viet Nam. The ensuing project will 
allow ADB to maximize the benefits of ongoing transport sector investments in the Northeastern 
Corridor. The project will also complement ongoing ADB-financed economic development and

poverty reduction activities in Houaphanh province in the Lao PDR and Thanh Hoa province in 
Viet Nam, contributing to the overall economic development of the corridor. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  A project design and feasibility study will be prepared for about 200 km of Route 217 in 
Thanh Hoa province in Viet Nam and about 140 km of sections of Routes 6, 6A, and 6B in 
Houaphanh province in the Lao PDR. The study will also prioritize a total of about 200 km of 
rural access roads linking the corridor to the hinterland of the Lao PDR and Viet Nam. To 
prepare  the  project,  the  TA  will  (i)  prepare  traffic  forecasts  for  project  roads;  (ii) prepare 
preliminary designs and cost estimates; (iii) complete an economic analysis of the proposed 
road improvements; (iv) analyze the environmental, social, resettlement, and  ethnic minority 
impacts of the project and prepare an initial environmental examination and resettlement plan 
including  ethnic  minority  specific  actions;  (v)  prepare  the  necessary  documentation  for 
approval of the projects by the governments of the Lao PDR and Viet Nam; and (vi) analyze 
and recommend improvements for implementation of cross-border movement of goods and 
people on the project roads.  
 
11.  The ensuing project is not expected to have any major negative environmental, social, or 
resettlement impact, as it consists of improvements to roads along existing alignments, with only 
limited use of new alignments to improve safety conditions. None of the roads passes through 
environmentally protected areas. The initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. The TA 
will include a full analysis of potential impacts and preparation of plans for mitigating them. The 
primary resettlement and land acquisition impact is expected to be the acquisition of narrow 
strips of land along the road alignment, with the relocation of a small number of households in 
the few places where adjustments to the alignment may be necessary. Many members of ethnic 
minorities live in parts of the project area. The concentration of ethnic minority populations is 
highest in the areas closest to the Lao PDR–Viet Nam border, and they are less integrated into 
mainstream society in these areas as well. Ethnic minorities are expected to benefit significantly 
from the project, as will the population in general. The stakeholder consultation carried out and 
the resettlement plan prepared under the TA will include components to ensure that ethnic 
minorities are not disadvantaged by the project and they and other vulnerable groups will be 
assisted to improve their socioeconomic status. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,600,000 equivalent. The governments of the 
Lao PDR and Viet Nam have asked ADB to provide $1,300,000 equivalent to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The governments 
will finance the balance of $300,000 equivalent by each providing $150,000 equivalent to cover 
the required office accommodation, remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff, and other 
items, mostly in kind. The governments have been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The cost estimates and financing plan for the TA 
are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agencies for the project will be the Lao PDR MPWT and the VRA under 
the  Ministry  of  Transport.  Both  MPWT  and  VRA  have  the  capacity  to  implement  the  TA 
successfully,  as  demonstrated  by  their  prior  experience  with  ADB-financed  projects.  The 
implementing agencies for the project will be MPWT’s Department of Roads (DOR) for the

5
Lao PDR and VRA’s Project Management Unit 1 (PMU1) for Viet Nam. The directors-general 
of DOR and PMU1 will be responsible for implementation of the TA in the Lao PDR and Viet 
Nam,  respectively.  The  governments  will  set  up  a  steering  committee  to  oversee  and 
coordinate all TA activities. The steering committee will be chaired jointly by the director-
generals of DOR and PMU1 and will be composed of representatives from other ministries 
and  agencies  of  the  national  and  local  governments  of  both  countries.  The  steering 
committee will meet periodically in Vientiane and Ha Noi. The governments will make a team 
of counterpart staff available to help the consultants carry out the TA in a timely manner. The 
executing agencies will provide office accommodation, local communication facilities, office 
support staff, and other administrative support. Project offices will be located in Vientiane and 
Ha Noi. 
 
14.  An international consulting firm in association with national consultants will be selected 
and engaged by ADB, using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost 
weighting of 80:20. ADB will apply its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time) in engaging consultants. The full technical proposal procedure will be used to 
select the consultants. A total of about 26 person-months of international and 84 person-months 
of national consulting services will be required. The consultants will have extensive experience 
in  (i)  highway,  bridge,  and  pavement  engineering;  (ii) traffic  forecasting  for  and  economic 
evaluation  of  road  projects;  (iii)  environmental,  resettlement,  social,  and  poverty  impact 
assessments, including ethnic minority issues; and (iv) transport sector and border-crossing 
institutional  issues.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in  Appendix  4. 
Advance action for recruitment of consultants has been approved. 
 
15.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  about  8  months,  beginning  in  October  2008  for 
completion by May 2009. The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1 month of 
commencing their services; (ii) an interim report within 3 months; (iii) a draft final report within  
6 months including the environmental, social, and poverty impact assessment reports and 
resettlement plan; and (iv) a final report within 3 weeks of receipt of comments from the 
governments and ADB. Tripartite meetings will be held after submission of the inception, interim, 
and draft final reports to review and endorse the reports. The location of the meetings will 
alternate between Vientiane and Ha Noi. The consultants will conduct workshops to discuss 
issues arising during the preparation of the interim and draft final reports, with two workshops 
each in Vientiane and Ha Noi. Equipment to be provided under the TA will be procured in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Office 
equipment purchased will be transferred to the executing agencies upon completion of the TA, 
and thereafter will remain the property of the governments.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,300,000.00 on a grant basis 
for Preparing the Second Northern Greater Mekong Subregion Transport Network Improvement 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy and the sector analysis describe how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy 
of the partner country. 
 
Both the Lao PDR and Viet Nam recognize the importance of regional cooperation in facilitating economic growth and 
reducing poverty. The Government of the Lao PDR has identified transport development as critical to achieving its 
development targets. The 2004 national growth and poverty eradication strategy states that the primary goal for 
transport is to “fully integrate the economy, thereby providing an enabling environment for trade and commerce and 
access for all Lao people to basic services”. Poverty reduction is a key focus of the Government’s current and long-
term (2020) development plan. Road access is considered one of the keys to eradicating poverty in the Lao PDR. 
Viet Nam’s socio-economic development program (2006–2010) is based on a strategy for pro-poor growth and 
poverty reduction. Viet Nam’s rapid reduction in poverty to date has arisen from its high rates of economic growth. To 
continue this progress, improvement of transport infrastructure is necessary, particularly in areas without easy access 
to major centers of economic activity. 
 
B.     Targeting Classification  
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention (GI)   Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, 
M2, etc.) 
 
2.   Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The TA will design a project that will reduce poverty by increasing economic growth for all residents of the project 
area as well as for people in the larger GMS region. The benefits of the project arising from improved transport 
infrastructure on the GMS Northeastern Corridor are available to all people regardless of income level. 
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
2. What resources are allocated in the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA)/due diligence? 
 
The TA includes international and national consulting services for poverty analysis as well as financing for conducting 
social surveys which will include collection of data for the poverty analysis.

3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
The scope of the TA includes rural access roads to maximize benefits for the rural poor (see below).  The social 
analysis to be conducted under the TA will determine if there are additional opportunities for pro-poor design. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
 
The potential primary beneficiaries of the project include the residents of Houaphanh province in the Lao PDR and 
Thanh Hoa province in Viet Nam, both of which have high rates of poverty. Houaphanh province in northeastern Lao 
PDR is one of the poorest provinces in the country. Five of its eight districts are included among the 47 poorest 
districts of the Lao PDR, and 78% of Houaphanh’s 758 villages are classified as poor with the majority of the 
population relying on upland agriculture. Thanh Hoa province is the northernmost province of Viet Nam’s central 
coastal provinces. Three of the five districts of the province through which the project road passes are designated as 
poor. The percentage of the population living below the poverty line in these three districts ranges from 24% to 59%. 
By improving the efficiency of transport in the GMS Northeastern Corridor and on associated rural access roads, the 
project prepared by the TA will provide opportunities for the poor and socially excluded to gain access to employment 
and trading opportunities arising from increased economic growth in the project area. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
The primary need is access to areas of the GMS with higher rates of economic growth and to markets for agricultural 
and other products produced in the project area. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints on accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
 
Poor access of remote communities to the roads comprising the GMS Northeastern Corridor could restrict the 
residents of these communities from benefiting from the ensuing project. The scope of the TA includes selection and 
design of improvement options for about 200 km of rural access roads (covering both countries) to ensure that people 
living in remote communities can benefit from the project.  
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
The potential initial stakeholders include people living in communities along the road; people in the project area, 
particularly farmers and producers of other goods that can be sold in markets; and road users, who will benefit from 
the completion of the GMS Northeastern Corridor’s linking of northern Lao PDR and northern Viet Nam, including 
Thanh Hoa.  
 
2. What type of consultation and participation is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)? 
 
During the TA, consultation will be carried out with stakeholders, including holding workshops for ethnic minorities 
and other residents of the project area and discussions with non-government organizations active in the project area.  
 
3. What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
     Information sharing     Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
4. Will a consultation and participation plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.

10  Appendix 2 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
1. What are the key gender issues in the sector and/or subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project or 
program? 
 
The improvement of the roads that comprise the GMS Northeastern Corridor will create new opportunities for 
women through jobs, small businesses, and better access to social services. However, the extent to which women 
can take advantage of these opportunities depends on economic, social, and cultural factors. The improved roads 
and increased traffic pose an increased risk for trafficking of women and children as well as HIV/AIDS transmission. 
The TA will conduct a gender analysis and, if necessary, prepare a gender strategy targeted at households affected 
by resettlement and communities that are at risk of increased HIV/AIDS transmission and human trafficking. The 
gender strategy will help women from affected households secure better access to compensation resources and 
livelihood activities under the resettlement plan, and will minimize the potential risk of HIV/AIDS and human 
trafficking in the communities. 
 
2.  Does  the  proposed  project  or  program  have  the  potential  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s 
empowerment  by  improving  women’s  access  to  and  use  of  opportunities,  services,  resources,  assets,  and 
participation in decision making?       Yes          No    Please explain.  
      The project will improve women’s access to employment opportunities and social services. 
 
3. Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or widen gender inequality? 
          Yes          No     The project will improve existing roads, and it is not expected to have any adverse 
impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality. The social analysis 
under the TA will confirm the nature of the impact.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will prepare a project to improve sections of the Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) Northeastern Corridor in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR) and Viet Nam. The TA will prepare a project design and feasibility study for Route 217 in 
Thanh Hoa province in Viet Nam and sections of Routes 6, 6A, and 6B in Houaphanh Province 
in Lao PDR. Route 217 covers 196 kilometers (km) from the junction with Route 1 at the town of 
Do Len (about 22 km north of the city of Thanh Hoa) to the Viet Nam–Lao PDR border at Na 
Meo. The roads in Lao PDR to be analyzed include 50 km of Route 6 from Viengxay to Na Meo 
on the border, 62 km of Route 6A from Hanglong to Sopbao at the junction with Route 6B, and 
24 km of Route 6B from Sopbao to the border post at Pahang. The consultants will also 
examine Route 6 from Kham to Viengxay (128 km) to identify sections of poor road geometry 
that impede heavy  vehicle traffic and recommend works to improve these locations to an 
appropriate road design standard. 
 
2.  The terms of reference for the consultants will include the following. 
 
A.  Technical Aspects  
3.  The consultants will prepare a project design and feasibility study to the level of detail of 
preliminary design sufficient to prepare a project suitable for Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
financing. To accomplish this, the consultants will carry out the following tasks.  
(i)  Undertake an engineering survey of the project roads, conduct all necessary 
testing  to  determine  existing  conditions,  identify  and  assess  viable  material 
sources for use during construction, and complete an assessment of drainage 
structures,  including  new  bridges.  Prepare  an  assessment  of  alternative 
pavement treatment methods for the different classes and vehicle loading on the 
project roads. 
 
(ii)  Based  on  the  results  of  the  engineering  survey  and  traffic  forecasts  and  in 
consultation with the governments and ADB, recommend the road classification 
standard, including the GMS class III standard and lower standards if appropriate, 
to be applied to each road. 
 
(iii)  Prepare the preliminary engineering design, including preliminary drawings with a 
GPS-based plan, profile, and typical cross section for project roads, including 
improvement of existing bridges and construction of new bridges.  
 
(iv)  Determine construction quantities, and prepare cost estimates for each road 
section based on the preliminary design.  
 
(v)  Prepare a prioritized list of about 100 km of rural access roads in each country 
for  improvement  under  the  project,  with  recommended  improvements  and 
estimated costs. The rural roads should be selected in cooperation with the 
executing agencies and in accordance with selection criteria agreed upon by 
ADB and the executing agencies with the objective of maximizing the coverage 
of the project benefits and to support the poverty eradication programs of the 
governments.

14  Appendix 4 
 
(vi)  Undertake road safety audits on each project road and incorporate the results in 
the preliminary design. 
 
(vii)  Define  the  project  implementation  and  procurement  arrangements,  including 
contract  packaging,  implementation  schedule,  organization  structure  and 
personnel so that the project is effectively prepared, managed, and implemented.   
 
B.  Traffic and Economic Analysis  
4.  The consultants will carry out the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Conduct traffic surveys for each road section at appropriate locations; conduct 
origin–destination and axle-load surveys to establish the pattern and volume of 
vehicle,  passenger,  and  cargo  movements,  including  details  of  passenger 
characteristics and types of freight being shipped. Assess the possibilities of 
passenger and freight traffic diversion from other routes. Prepare traffic forecasts 
by  representative  vehicle  type,  taking  into  account  economic  and  population 
growth;  production  and  increases  in  economic  activity;  and  income  in  the 
hinterland of the project road.  
 
(ii)  Calculate  economic  vehicle  operating  costs  for  each  road  section  with  and 
without  the  proposed  improvements,  based  on  estimated  changes  in  road 
surface roughness. Quantify the benefits using shadow prices for each project 
road  section  and  for  each  improvement  option,  including  time  savings  from 
improved road conditions, road maintenance savings, and fewer traffic accidents, 
as appropriate. Benefits arising from the improvement of rural access roads 
should be calculated and shown separately. 
 
(iii)  Assess  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  and  net  present  value  by 
homogeneous  road  section  based  on  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Economic 
Analysis of Projects (1997). Derive appropriate sensitivity and switching values 
by  varying  the  major  parameters  affecting  project  viability.  Conduct  a  full 
distribution  analysis  including  distribution  of  benefits  among  countries  in  the 
region,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Handbook  for  Economic  Analysis  of 
Subregional Projects, and among project beneficiaries and stakeholders. The 
economic analysis will evaluate the alternatives using HDM IV1 or a similar 
model, and will assess the total life cycle costs. The analysis must identify risks 
and undertake a risk and sensitivity analysis of the economic internal rate of 
return in accordance with ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the 
Economic Analysis of Projects (2002). 
 
C.  Environmental Assessment  
5.  The consultants will carry out the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Carry out consultations with stakeholders, including ethnic minorities and other 
residents of the project area and nongovernment organizations, in compliance 
with the governments’ and ADB’s guidelines. 
 
                                                 
1  Highway development and management software, version IV.

Appendix 4  15 
(ii)  Prepare an initial environmental examination and the related summary initial 
environmental  examination  for  each  country,  in  accordance  with  the 
governments’ environmental guidelines, ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), and 
ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). The initial environmental 
examination will follow ADB’s format and include the following: (a) a description 
of the project including a description of the government’s legal and administrative 
framework  of  environmental  assessment  of  the  project,  (b)  a  description  of 
existing environmental conditions in the project area, (c) identification of potential 
impacts  and  corresponding  mitigation  measures  during  preconstruction, 
construction  and  operation  phases,  including  cumulative  impacts,  (d)  an 
environmental management plan, (e) a description of public involvement and 
disclosure activities, and (f) conclusions. 
 
(iii)  Prepare an environmental management plan (EMP) that will include: (a) details 
of  the  environmental  mitigation  and  monitoring  program  to  be  implemented;  
(b)  clear  definition  of  institutional  arrangements  for  EMP  implementation;  
(c)  assessment  of  current  institutional  capacity  to  implement  the  EMP  and 
requirements  for  capacity  building/institutional  strengthening  activities;  and  
(d)  scope,  budget,  schedule  and  frequency,  location,  and  responsibilities  for 
implementation  of  environmental  mitigation,  monitoring  and  capacity 
building/institutional strengthening activities. 
 
D.  Social, Poverty, and Resettlement Impact Analysis   
6.  The consultants will carry out the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Collect quantitative and qualitative data in the field and prepare socioeconomic 
profiles  of  the  affected  communities  in  the  project  area  in  accordance  with  
(a) relevant ADB policies and operations manuals, including those for involuntary 
resettlement; and (b) the requirements of the governments. The consultants will 
use ADB guidelines and publications, including the handbooks on poverty and 
social analysis and resettlement as guides.2 The profiles will cover gender and 
local ethnic minorities, and will be in a format that can be updated at project 
completion and again during post evaluation.  
 
(ii)  Undertake a social and gender analysis as per ADB's policies on involuntary 
resettlement, indigenous peoples, as well as gender and development and their 
respective  operations  manuals. 3   The  consultants  will  use  relevant  ADB 
guidelines and publications, including the gender checklist on resettlement and 
the guide on consultation and participation.4 They will review and assess the 
impacts of land acquisition or loss of land use on project-affected people by 
gender and ethnic group (in terms of loss of homes or of agricultural and other 
types of land, as well as loss of access to current income-generating activities), 
including impacts caused by permanent or temporary land acquisition. 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2006. Poverty Handbook Analysis and Processes to Support ADB Operations: A Working Document. Manila; 
and ADB. 2007. Handbook on Social Analysis. Manila. Available: http://www.adb.org/Documents/Others/Social-
Analysis-Toolkit/sat0300.asp  
3  ADB. 1998. Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice. Manila; ADB. 1998. Policy on Indigenous 
Peoples. Manila; and ADB. 2003. Policy on Gender and Development. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2003. Gender Checklist: Resettlement. Manila; and ADB. 2006 Strengthening Participation for Development 
Results: A Staff Guide to Consultation and Participation. Manila.

16  Appendix 4 
 
 
(iii)  Determine the extent to which a gender strategy is required to maximize the 
benefits  of  the  project.  Prepare  a  gender  strategy,  including  gender-specific 
livelihood programs for the resettlement plan; awareness raising for women on 
human trafficking and HIV/AIDS based on existing programs being implemented 
in the project area; a training needs and training plan for the executing agencies, 
if necessary, in implementing the gender strategy; a detailed budget for the 
strategy with full terms of reference; and an implementation schedule.   
 
(iv)  Conduct an analysis of ethnic minorities in the project area, including determining 
where ethnic minority communities are located in the project area, and studying 
the type, scale, nature, and magnitude of impacts the project will have on them 
(including  impacts  during  and  after  project  implementation  as  well  as  other 
sociocultural and economic impacts). 
 
(v)  Evaluate  poverty  in  the  project  area.  Describe  the  incidence  of  poverty  and 
assess the causes of poverty and extent to which the project will address them, 
including the impact on ethnic minorities and other vulnerable groups. Identify 
potential barriers keeping the poor from benefiting from economic growth and 
recommend interventions that could maximize poverty reduction (seasonal and 
long-term) for poor households. They will estimate (a) wage job opportunities 
(person-days)  for  poor  households  during  construction,  and  (b)  general  job 
opportunities in improving the transport network. Analyze the potential poverty 
impact of the project, including the impact from increased tourism and other 
economic activity arising from the project. When negative impacts are identified, 
mitigation measures will be developed and their costs estimated. 
 
(vi)  Review relevant development activities, as well as poverty reduction and sector 
strategies, by government agencies and development institutions and examine 
their impact on economic development, trade, and poverty reduction. 
 
(vii)  Prepare resettlement plans for the project (one for each country) in accordance 
with relevant ADB policies and operations manuals, including the involuntary 
resettlement  policy  and  operations  manual.  The  resettlement  plans  should 
include measures to ensure that ethnic minorities are not disadvantaged as a 
result of land acquisition or other resettlement impacts and should be developed 
in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples. Use ADB’s handbook 
on resettlement as a guide (footnote 3). Fully involve all stakeholders, include 
executing and implementing agencies, and take into account the requirements of 
the governments. Assess the need to improve the capacities of the executing 
agencies to implement resettlement plans, and develop a training plan. 
 
E.  Institutional Analysis and Project Preparation 
7.  The consultants will carry out the following tasks.    
(i)  Work with the consultants for ADB’s regional TA for Enhancing Transport and 
Trade  Facilitation  in  the  GMS 5   to  develop  specific  recommendations  for 
improving the efficiency of cross-border movement of passengers and cargo at 
                                                 
5  ADB.  2008.  Technical  Assistance  for  Enhancing  Transport  and  Trade  Facilitation  in  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion. Manila.

Appendix 4  17 
the  border  crossings  on  the  project  roads,  including  implementing  the  GMS 
Cross-Border Transport Agreement and coordinating with other agencies. 
 
(ii)  Design  a  project  performance  monitoring  system  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  Project  Performance  Monitoring  (1999).  Develop  a  detailed 
evaluation and monitoring framework for the ensuing project, including impacts, 
outcomes, and outputs with corresponding measurable performance indicators 
and targets, monitoring mechanisms, risks, and assumptions. For the specified 
indicators, (a) establish procedures for their collection, (b) provide cost estimates 
for benefit monitoring and evaluation in terms of ADB’s guidelines for benefit 
monitoring  and  evaluation, 6   and  (c)  develop  a  baseline  database  for 
socioeconomic parameters.  
 
(iii)  Identify agencies responsible for monitoring activities and when these activities 
should be undertaken. 
 
(iv)  Review the executing agencies’ capacity for implementing all components of the 
project, including local governments involved with implementing the rural roads 
component of the project, and recommend measures for strengthening capacity. 
 
(v)  Conduct a financial management assessment of the Ministry of Public Works and 
Transport and the Ministry of Transport, highlighting strengths and weaknesses 
of  the  financial  management  system.  Describe  the  accounting  and  audit 
processes  and  procedures.  Include  document  and  fund  flows  with  particular 
attention to the integrity and completeness of auditing. Recommend actions for 
addressing weaknesses, if any. 
 
(vi)  Prepare a draft report and recommendation of the President, in ADB format 
including all relevant appendixes, for submission of the project for approval by 
ADB’s Board of Directors.  
 
(vii)  Prepare the feasibility study required by the Government of Viet Nam for its 
internal approval of the project, based on the design and analysis carried out 
under the preceding sections of these terms of reference. The feasibility study for 
the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  should  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the 
Common  General  Guidelines  on  Feasibility  Study  Preparation  for  Official 
Development Assistance Projects attached to the Decision No. 48/2008/QD-TTg 
issued by the Prime Minister on 3 April 2008.
